Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering Northwestern University 2145 Sheridan Road Evanston IL 60208 United States Graphical abstract Methane dehydroaromatization (MDA) enables the catalytic conversion of methane into aromatics, mainly benzene, along with hydrogen, in a single-step process under non-oxidative conditions. In this study, we prepared a series of isomorphously substituted Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts with exclusively isolated or low-oligomerized sites up to 3.2 % Fe weight loading by adding ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) to the crystallization gel. These catalysts exhibit no induction/activation period and a significantly higher maximum product yield compared to Fe/ZSM-5 catalysts prepared by the incipient wetness impregnation method and containing extensively aggregated FeOx. This investigation focuses on the evolution of Fe sites during the post-synthetic treatments. Most importantly, we demonstrate the quantitative relation between Fe site isolation and catalytic activity, proving that isolated or low-oligomerized Fe species at the exchange sites formed during post-synthetic treatment are the active sites for methane activation. Keywords Methane Dehydroaromatization Fe-ZSM-5 Active sites Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Natural gas, predominantly composed of methane, represents a globally distributed source of fossil fuel energy. There is significant interest in the conversion of this abundant resource into value-added chemicals, rather than direct combustion as a fuel source [1–3]. Among all the strategies, methane dehydroaromatization (MDA) offers a promising transformation pathway, wherein methane is converted into aromatics (principally benzene) and H2 through a one-step reaction under non-oxidative conditions [4–7]. Mo/ZSM-5, the benchmark catalyst for MDA, has been extensively studied since its initial report by Wang et al. in 1993 [8]. However, the commercialization of this catalyst still faces significant challenges: the Mo/ZSM-5 catalyst undergoes noticeable deactivation during the regeneration process [9,10], which is designed to restore its activity following substantial coke formation. In response to these challenges, research has actively pursued alternative metals and structures aiming for alternatives that offer both stability and comparable activity [11–15]. Fe/ZSM-5 has been drawing growing attention because of its earth abundance and MDA activity that is only somewhat lower than that of Mo/ZSM-5 [11,16]. Unlike Mo constituents, which are volatile at the relevant preparation and reaction temperatures [17], the structure of Fe/ZSM-5 depends closely on the synthetic method [18]. This laboratory previously reported that increasing the dispersion of Fe species in Fe/ZSM-5 leads to a shorter induction/activation period and a higher benzene yield [19]. A similar conclusion was made by Gu et al., [20] who employed a grinding synthetic method to prepare a Fe/ZSM-5 characterized by predominantly isolated or low-oligomerized sites. Both ex-situ and in-situ characterizations show that these isolated or low-oligomerized Fe sites undergo a rapid reduction to form active suboxides, resulting in a shorter induction/activation period and a higher product yield. In contrast, bulk iron oxide particles are successively reduced and carbonized to iron carbide species, suppressing catalytic activity. However, the formation of larger iron oxide clusters and particles is generally inevitable by post-synthetic preparation methods with high Fe loadings [21]. The maximum exchange of charge-balancing cations is claimed to be approximately 70 % [22], with the exception ofthe solid-state exchange [23] methods and Feng-Hall methods, where they prepared overexchanged Fe/ZSM-5 catalysts by minimizing the oxidation of Fe2+ to Fe3+ [24]. To further enhance the Fe dispersion, isomorphous substitution, which involves the incorporation of Fe precursors as synthesis blocks during the zeolite crystallization, is naturally considered. Isomorphously substituted Fe-ZSM-5 has recently been investigated for application in the MDA reaction, and various mechanisms have been proposed to elucidate the active sites. Liu et al. [25] employed operando X-ray Absorption Near Edge Spectroscopy (XANES) and proposed that the Fe3+ sites, both framework and extra-framework Fe sites, are reduced in the CH4 flow to catalytically active Fe2+. In contrast, Deng et al. [26] proposed that the framework Fe sites dissociate, aggregate, and further undergo reduction and carbonization to form Fe carbide species under the reaction conditions. A limitation of both studies is the use of the conventional synthesis method with tetrapropylammonium hydroxide (TPAOH) as the organic structure-directing agent, which leads to relatively low metal weight loadings and the formation of Fe oxide particles. Furthermore, both studies did not optimize the post-synthetic treatment methods, resulting in a very limited formation of isolated or low-oligomeric Fe species at the exchange sites. A lengthy activation period (∼300 min) and a relatively low activity were reported by both studies, indicating that framework Fe sites and Fe oxide aggregates may not exhibit immediate activity for the MDA reaction and require a specific activation process. In this work, we adopted the synthetic method developed by Yuan et al. [27], whereby ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) is introduced into the zeolite synthesis gel. This addition aims to stabilize the Fe precursor, preventing its hydrolysis and subsequent aggregation in the basic zeolite crystallization gel. Owing to the chelating properties of EDTA, an as-synthesized Fe-ZSM-5 catalyst was prepared, featuring up to 3.2 % Fe weight loading and exclusively atomically dispersed Fe sites within the zeolite framework. After post-synthetic treatment, the H-form of these catalysts is immediately active upon introducing a methane flow and exhibits high activities (∼5 % maximum benzene yield) under MDA conditions. Building on prior work understanding the in-situ formation of active catalysts from more or less dispersed catalysts under MDA conditions, here we sought to understand how pre-catalyst structure evolves and ultimately leads to high catalytic activity. This investigation concentrates on the evolution of Fe sites during post-synthetic treatments, which include calcination to remove EDTA and obtain the Na-form, ion-exchange to produce the NH4-form, and further activation to obtain the catalytically active H-form. Most importantly, we propose novel active sites, demonstrating that only the isolated or low-oligomerized extra-framework Fe sites generated in the post-synthetic treatment are active in methane activation. Finally, we quantitively correlate these sites with the catalytic activity, providing further support for the proposed active sites. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation The Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts were synthesized by a previously published direct synthesis (DS) procedure with minor modifications [27]. Fumed silica (Sigma), aluminum sulfate octadecahydrate (Sigma, >97 %), and ferric chloride (Sigma, anhydrous), were used as silicon, aluminum and iron sources. Sodium hydroxide (Sigma, pellets, >97 %) was utilized to digest the silicon source and to provide an alkaline crystallization environment. Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid disodium salt dihydrate (EDTA·2Na·2H2O, Sigma, 99 %) was added to stabilize Fe3+ against hydrolysis in the alkaline synthesis gel. The molar composition of the synthesis gel is 100SiO2: 2Al2O3: 30Na2O: (2–5) EDTA: (2–5)Fe: 6000H2O. In a typical synthesis with a targeted weight loading of 2 %, 725 mg NaOH was dissolved in 10 mL deionized water, and 1.8 g fumed silica was added to the alkaline solution under rigorous stir at RT. The mixture was aged overnight to form clear solution A. Solution B was prepared by dissolving 400 mg Al2 (SO4)3·9H2O in 10 mL deionized water and was added to solution A dropwise. The mixture was aged at RT for 2 h under vigorous stirring. Solution C was prepared by dissolving 97.32 mg FeCl3 and 223.3 mg EDTA·2Na·2H2O at 80 °C. The yellowish solution was added dropwise to the prepared aluminosilicate gel at 80 °C. The gel was aged at 80 °C for 2 h before 100 mg of zeolite seed (Zeolyst, Si/Al2 = 23) was added. The gel was then aged at RT overnight before being transferred to a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The crystallization was conducted in a muffle furnace at 180 °C for 5 days with a 5 °C/min ramp rate. The solids were collected by vacuum filtration, followed by a thorough wash with water. Thereafter, the materials were dried in air at 80 °C overnight. The obtained catalysts are denoted as DS-as-X%, where DS stands for direct synthesis, as stands for as-synthesized, and X is the weight loading of Fe determined by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES). In the accompanying Figures, DS was neglected for simplicity. The synthesis of Fe-Silicalite-1 was carried out utilizing the identical procedure as previously described, with the exception of excluding the aluminum source and adding 5.0 mL of 25 % tetrapropylammonium hydroxide (TPAOH) solution (Thermo Scientific, 25 % in water) to direct crystallization. The obtained material is denoted as Fe-Silicalite-1-as-X%. The as-synthesized Fe-ZSM-5 and Fe-Silicalite-1 materials were calcined in static air at 550 °C (1 °C/min ramp) for 6 h to remove the organic contents, and are denoted as DS-Na-X% and Fe-Silicalite-1-Na-X%, where Na stands for Na-form. The materials in their Na-form were next ion-exchanged three times with a 1.0 M NH4NO3 solution to yield the NH4-form (DS-NH4-X% and Fe-Silicalite-1-NH4-X%). Unless explicitly stated, the NH4-Fe-ZSM-5 and NH4-Fe-Silicalite-1 powders were directly activated via a calcination in static air at 550 °C (1 °C/min ramp) for 3 h to obtain the H-form (DS-H-X% and Fe-Silicalite-1-X%) without further drying. A synthetic scheme is given in the supporting information for a clear illustration (Fig. S1). A reference sample, Fe/ZSM-5-IWI, was prepared by conventional incipient wetness impregnation. Before preparation, the parent NH4-ZSM-5 (Zeolyst, Si/Al2 = 23) was activated by calcination at 550 °C (1 °C/min ramp) for 3 h in static air. The pore volume of H-ZSM-5 was measured by N2 physisorption. Then, the Fe precursor, Fe(NO3)3·9H2O (Sigma, >98 %), was dissolved in deionized water with the calculated pore volume. The Fe3+ solution was added into H-ZSM-5 powders with vigorous stirring. The obtained powder was dried at 80 °C overnight, followed by a calcination at 550 °C (1 °C/min ramp) for 3 h. 2.2 Catalyst Characterization The Fe, Al, and Si contents were determined by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) on a Thermo iCAP 7600 instrument. The detailed information of sample digestion and measurement is given in the Supporting Information. The structure and crystallinity of synthesized Fe-ZSM-5 and Fe-Silicalite-1 were confirmed by X-ray diffraction (XRD) with a Rigaku Ultima Diffractometer using a Cu-source at 40 kV and 35 mA with a scanning rate of 10°/min in a 2θ range of 5–60°. The crystallinity of the materials was calculated by integrating the peak area of 2θ from 22.5 to 25° and referenced to a commercial ZSM-5 sample [28]. N2-physisorption isotherms were collected on a Micrometrics ASAP 2010 instrument. Prior to the measurement, ∼50 mg powder was degassed under dynamic vacuum for 16 h at 350 °C with a heating ramp of 1 °C/min. The surface area was determined by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method from the model applied to the adsorption branch of the isotherm. And the total pore volume was measured at p/p0 = 0.994. 27Al magic spinning nuclear magnetic resonance (MAS-NMR) spectroscopy experiments were carried out on a Bruker Avance III (HD 400 MHz) with a 4 mm MAS probe and 10 kHz rotational speed. The spectra were referenced to solid AlCl3·6H2O at 0 ppm. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were acquired on a Hitachi SU8030 instrument. The samples were coated with a thin layer of osmium oxide before measurement. Diffuse reflectance UV–visible (DRUV–vis) spectra of the as-synthesized, Na-, NH4-, and H- form catalysts were measured immediately after drying/calcination on a Cary 5000 UV–Vis NIR spectrophotometer equipped with a Harrick Praying Mantis accessory. The baseline was collected on polytetrafluoroethylene (Sigma). All the Raman spectra were acquired with 355 nm laser (Hubner photonics, Cobolt Zouk) excitation at 12 mW on an about 200 µm spot. A back scattering geometry was employed via a 90° off-axis parabolic mirror (Thorlabs) and a long-pass edge filter with a 150 cm−1 cut-off (Semrok, razor edge). Scattered light was collected via fiberoptics and sent to a Horiba iH50 triple monochromator/spectrometer. A 2400 line/mm grating was employed with a center at 363 nm. An average of 3 spectra with a 150 sec exposure was utilized to obtain the reported Raman spectra. Transient kinetic measurements were conducted by using a Micromeritics Autochem III instrument. The sample was flushed in He (Airgas, UHP grade, further dried over a Restek Triple Gas Filter) flowing at 30 sccm for 15 min and ramped to 730 °C with a ramp rate of 3 °C/min. At 730 °C, the gas was switched to a 50:50 mixture of He and 50 % CH4 in balance with Ar (Airgas, certified grade) flowing at 30 sccm. This flow was maintained for 30 min before it was switched back to He flowing at 30 sccm. The samples were cooled down to ambient under flowing He. The carrier (He, m/z = 4), tracer (Ar, m/z = 40), methane (m/z = 16) and product channels for ethylene (m/z = 27), ethane (m/z = 30), propylene (m/z = 41), propane (m/z = 29), benzene (m/z = 78) and toluene (m/z = 91) were monitored continuously by using a MKS Cirrus II mass spectrometer with time intervals of 1.28 sec. Mass spectra were corrected for the sensitivity factors and fragmentation patterns of standards. The calibration curves were obtained for 10 % C2H4 in balance with Ar (airgas, certified grade) and 10 % C3H6 in balance with N2 (Airgas, certified grade) in the 1–5 mol % range in He flowing at 100 sccm. The calibration curves for benzene and toluene were obtained by using the built-in vapor generator in the Autochem III instrument from HPLC/spectroscopic grade benzene (Sigma) and toluene (Acros Organics) without further purification. The vapor pressures of benzene and toluene were calculated by using the Antoine equation with parameters reported by Williamham, Taylor, et al., 1945 (benzene) [29] and Besley and Bottomley, 1974 (toluene) [30], respectively. NH3-TPD measurements were performed by using the Micromeritics’ Autochem III instrument. The samples were dehydrated at 730 °C by a temperature ramp of 3 °C/min and isothermal hold for 30 min. 10 %NH3 in balance with He (Airgas, certified grade) was flown at 30 sccm at 100 °C for 1 h, followed by purging with He flowing at 30 sccm for 1 h. TPD was carried out in the 100–730 °C range with a ramp rate of 10 °C/min. the desorbed products were monitored by using a TCD detector and a MKS Cirrus II mass spectrometer. Ion mass channels of 16,17,18 and 4 were recorded. m/z = 17 was used for NH3 after correcting for sensitivity and fragment contribution from H2O. The Fe K edge XAS experiments were conducted at Brookhaven National Laboratory (BNL) National Synchrotron Light Source II (NSLS-II) 8-ID ISS beamline. Samples were ground into a fine powder and then pressed as wafers, which were loaded into the sample holder and sealed with Kapton tapes. The samples were scanned in fluorescence mode in the received condition, i.e., exposed to air at RT. Two ion chambers with the Fe foil in between were placed behind the sample to calibrate the energy. Fe foil was used to calibrate the XAS K-edge spectra at 7.112 keV. The energy of the pre-edge peak was used to define the oxidation state of the Fe in the samples using FeO and Fe2O3 as reference compounds. WinXAS 4.0 software was used to analyze the data. The XANES were normalized with linear and second-order polynomials in the pre-edge and post-edge regions, respectively. The oxidation state was determined from the edge energy, which is the inflection of the leading edge of the XANES. 2.3 Catalytic reaction performance evaluation MDA reactions were conducted under atmospheric pressure conditions. Unless specifically mentioned, a U-shaped quartz reactor was loaded with 200 mg of the catalyst. The temperature of the catalyst was ramped from ambient to 730 °C at a heating rate of 7 °C/min under a He flow of 20 sccm. Subsequently, the catalyst was subjected to a stream of 5 % Ar/95 % CH4 at 18 sccm for catalytic activity assessment. The analysis of all reactants and products was performed using gas chromatography (Agilent 7890A). For the detection of hydrocarbons, an HP-PLOT-Q column (30 m × 0.53 mm × 40 µm) was utilized in conjunction with a flame ionization detector (FID). In parallel, a Molesieve column (30 m × 0.32 mm × 25 µm) connected to a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) was employed for the measurement of inert gases, using Ar as an internal standard. The calculations for methane conversion, product selectivity, and product yield were based on equations 1–4, (1) y Ar i n F i n = y Ar o u t F o u t (2) C o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = y C H 4 i n F i n - y C H 4 o u t F o u t y C H 4 i n F i n × 100 = 1 - y C H 4 o u t y A r i n y C H 4 i n y A r o u t × 100 (3) H y d r o c a r b o n S e l e c t i v i t y % = y C n H m o u t F o u t × n y C H 4 i n F i n - y C H 4 o u t F o u t × 100 = y A r i n y C n H m o u t × n y C H 4 i n y A r o u t - y C H 4 o u t y Ar i n × 100 (4) H y d r o c a r b o n Y i e l d = C o n v e r s i o n × S e l e c t i v i t y here F i n and F o u t are the inlet and outlet molar fluxes, and y C H 4 i n and y C H 4 o u t represent the CH4 mole fraction obtained by the TCD in the bypass mode, and the effluent. Similarly, y Ar i n and y Ar o u t represent the Ar mole fraction in the feed and effluent obtained by the TCD, and y C n H m o u t represent the CnHm mole fraction obtained by the FID analysis of the effluent. 3 Results and Discussion 3.1 Synthesis of Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts As-synthesized Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts with different Fe weight loadings were prepared via hydrothermal methods by adjusting the quantities of Fe precursor and EDTA·2Na incorporated into the synthesis gel, while maintaining all other synthesis parameters constant. These batch-to-batch variabilities were intentionally designed to study the role of various structures, as discussed in the later sections. ICP-OES was employed to analyze the elemental contents of the catalysts, and the results are listed in Table 1 . All materials exhibit comparable Si/Al ratios. Note that the Fe weight loadings did not change during post-synthetic treatments. Discussions below will utilize the Fe weight loadings of the H-form materials for consistency. The structure and crystallinity of the as-synthesized and H-form Fe-ZSM-5 samples were determined by PXRD (Fig. 1 ). All Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts in both as-synthesized form and H-form exhibit characteristic MFI structure peaks at 2θ of 7.9°, 8.8°, 23.2°, 24.0° and 24.5°, corresponding to the (0 1 1), (2 0 0), (5 0 1), (3 0 3) and (1 3 3) facets of HZSM-5 zeolite (JCPDS: No. 042-0664).[31] Furthermore, all materials exhibit crystallinity exceeding 90 %, and this crystallinity remains unchanged throughout post-synthetic treatment process, indicating that the structure of the catalysts was preserved. The physical properties of H-form materials were investigated by N2 physisorption (Fig. S2). A Type I isotherm, characteristic of microporous structures, was observed for all catalysts [32,33]. Additionally, N2 physisorption analyses revealed similar values for BET surface areas and total pore volumes across the catalysts. The morphologies of the as-synthesized Fe-ZSM-5 materials were characterized by SEM, and the images are provided in the Supporting Information (Fig. S3). All five materials are composed of complex aggregates with a variety of sizes and random morphologies. Increasing EDTA tends to make longer and thinner crystals, suggesting that EDTA plays a role in directing the crystal growth orientation. The Al coordination environment of the Fe-ZSM-5 materials in the as-synthesized form and H-form was investigated by 27Al MAS NMR, and the results are shown in Fig. 2 . The signals at 55 ppm and 0 ppm can be attributed to tetra- and hexa-coordinated Al sites [34]. The two weak peaks at −40 and 155 ppm are spinning side bands because of the quadrupolar 27Al nuclei [35]. The as-synthesized Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts only contain tetracoordinate Al sites. After post-synthetic treatment, hexacoordinated Al sites are present in the H-form variants at levels typical of commercial ZSM-5. 3.2 Evolution of Fe sites in Fe-ZSM-5 from as-synthesized to H-form catalysts The ICP-OES, PXRD, and N2-physisorption data discussed above confirm that the experimental Fe-ZSM-5 samples have physical properties similar to commercial ZSM-5. This section will focus on examining the iron sites and their evolution throughout the post-synthetic treatment process. Considering that the sensitivity of PXRD is generally limited to detecting Fe2O3 particles larger than 2 nm, this technique can also provide some insights into the dispersion of iron species in the material. As shown in the zoomed-in PXRD patterns of both as-synthesized and H-form Fe-ZSM-5 materials with 2θ of 30–50˚ (Fig. S4), there is no evidence for peaks at 33.1°, 35.6°, 40.8°, and 49.5°, corresponding to the (1 0 4), (1 1 0), (1 1 3), and (0 2 4) facet of hematite (Fe2O3, JCPDS No. 033-0664). This indicates a high dispersion of iron species in both as-synthesized and H-form. Direct visual inspection offers initial insights into the iron dispersion within Fe-ZSM-5 materials [36]. As illustrated in Fig. S5, all the as-synthesized Fe-ZSM-5 samples display a pure white color, indicative of a high degree of metal dispersion. As the post-synthetic treatments progress, the powders begin to exhibit a slight pale-yellow color. Based on the observed color change, it is speculated that some of the framework iron may migrate to form isolated or low-oligomeric iron species during the post-synthetic treatment process. The color of these materials is in stark contrast to the Fe/ZSM-5-IWI reference sample, which is an intense red–orange, indicating the formation of large iron oxide domains. Detailed characterizations of iron speciation, including UV–Vis, Raman, and XANES, are given in the subsequent text below. UV–Vis spectroscopy is another powerful technique for identifying the coordination state of Fe, with the observed bands generally attributable to (1) framework Fe sites (200–250 nm), (2) isolated or low-oligomerized Fe sites at the cationic exchange sites (250–350 nm), (3) iron oxide clusters (350–450 nm), and (4) large iron oxide particles at the external surfaces of the zeolites (>450 nm) [37–40]. Note that the spectra of the as-synthesized Fe-ZSM-5 materials exhibit bands exclusively below 250 nm, indicating that all the Fe sites are integrated in the zeolite framework (Fig. 3 a). Following the removal of the EDTA by calcination, a small signal is observed around 270 nm (Fig. 3b). This suggests that only a limited amount of the framework Fe sites have migrated to form extra-framework Fe species in the first calcination. In contrast, the H-form catalysts feature a pronounced change in the UV–Vis spectra for all five materials (Fig. 3c). Specifically, there is an increase in absorbance within the 250–350 nm region, which we interpret as the migration of framework Fe species to cationic exchange sites and the formation of isolated or low-oligomerized Fe sites. In Fig. 3d, the UV–Vis spectrum of Fe/ZSM-5-IWI reference catalyst is plotted for comparison. Apparently, the Fe/ZSM-5-IWI is a mixture of several Fe species, including isolated or low-oligomerized Fe sites as well as Fe oxide clusters and particles. Distinct catalytic behavior is anticipated for the catalysts prepared by incipient wetness impregnation (IWI) versus those prepared by direct synthesis (DS). For enhanced visualization, the UV–Vis spectra of Fe-ZSM-5-DS-2.58 % in its as-synthesized form, as well as in its Na-, NH4-, and H-forms, have been collectively plotted in Fig. 3d. The spectra of as-synthesized, Na- and NH4- are nearly identical, whereas the spectrum of the H-form exhibits a significant difference. This observation indicates that the migration of Fe sites occurred during the second calcination process, leading to the formation of the extra-framework Fe species. To further explore the difference between these materials, Na-, NH4-, and H-form Fe-ZSM-5-DS-2.58 % were subjected to MDA tests, and the results are shown in Fig. 4 and Fig. S6. The Na-form catalyst yields negligible methane conversion, with no benzene yield observed throughout the entire 10-hour duration of the experiment. In addition, despite the Fe species in the NH4-form appearing similar to those in the Na-form, the NH4-form exhibits a maximum benzene yield of 1.7 % and a maximum methane conversion of 4.5 %. Most notably, the H-form catalyst exhibits a maximum benzene yield of 5.3 %, accompanied by a maximum methane conversion of 9.9 %, which is over twice as that observed for the NH4-form catalyst. These conversions and benzene yields begin to approach those of a benchmark Mo/ZSM-5 catalyst which was tested under the same conditions (Fig. S7). Because of the apparent difference between the UV–Vis spectra of H-form and other-form catalysts, this observation leads us to hypothesize that an activation through calcination subsequent to the ion-exchange process, during which time extra-framework Fe sites within the cation exchange sites of the zeolite framework are formed, is essential for achieving the high MDA catalytic activity of Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts. Fig. S8 shows the Raman spectra of Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts in the H-form. The bands at 383 and 808 cm−1 are attributed to the characteristic features of the MFI zeolite structure [41,42]. Bands observed at 515, 1007, and 1155 cm−1 across five samples are related to the framework Fe sites [43,44]. Among these, the features at 515 and 1155 cm−1 correspond to the symmetric and antisymmetric stretching vibrations of the framework Feδ+-O-Si structure [45]. Notably, a band at 880 cm−1 is present in all five spectra, and is associated with the symmetrically coupled vibration of bridged binuclear Fe2(µ-O2) species at the cationic exchange sites [21,46,47]. Overall, the Raman spectra of the Fe-ZSM-5-DS-H catalysts confirm the existence of both framework Fe sites and extra-framework Fe species, consistent with the findings from the aforementioned UV–Vis spectroscopic investigations. XAS measurements were next conducted on Fe-ZSM-5-DS-2.58 % samples in their as-, Na-, and H-forms to investigate the coordination environments of Fe within these materials, and the spectra are plotted in Fig. 5 a and the pre-edge and edge energies are summarized in Table 2 . All materials exhibit a pre-edge peak at 7.114 keV, corresponding to the 1s-3d dipole forbidden transition of Fe3+ [48,49]. The pre-edge intensity is identical in the as- and Na-form materials, indicating that the Fe coordination environment remains constant throughout the initial calcination process. This finding is consistent with the UV–Vis analysis above, which indicates minimal Fe migration during the EDTA removal. The pre-edge intensity decreases when converted to the H-form material. This suggests a partial transition from framework Fe species to Fe at extra-framework locations [16,50–52], since pre-edge peak intensities are known to be higher with decreasing coordination number of iron complexes due to loss of inversion symmetry at the iron site [48]. For example, tetrahedral Fe complexes generally have a higher pre-edge peak intensity than the octahedral ones [53,54]. This observation again aligns with the results of UV–Vis and Raman analyses arguing that the framework Fe sites partially migrate to the extra-framework positions during the activation process. Fig. 5b shows the k2-weighted Fourier-transformed EXAFS spectra of Fe-ZSM-5-DS materials in their as-, Na-, and H-forms. Additionally, the spectra of Fe2O3 and FeO are included as references. The Fe-ZSM-5-DS materials, irrespective of their form (as-, Na-, or H-form), exhibit a singular pronounced peak approximately at 1.4 Å (phase uncorrected distance), which is attributable to Fe-O scattering. This indicates that Fe sites are highly dispersed in the materials without the formation of bulky aggregates. In contrast, the spectra of references, Fe2O3 and FeO, display multiple Fe···O···Fe peaks, reflecting the presence of varied interactions attributable to large oxide clusters. To summarize, characterizations, including UV–Vis and XANES, demonstrate the evolution of Fe species in the post-synthetic treatment procedure. The significant differences in catalytic activity among the Na-, NH4-, and H-form catalysts suggest that in-framework Fe species, present in the as-synthesized and Na-forms, exhibit relatively low activity. These species become catalytically more active when they migrate to extra-framework exchange sites, leading to the formation of isolated or low-oligomerized Fe species. 3.3 Correlation between active site properties and catalytic activity In the previous section, we established a qualitative correlation between the UV–Vis spectra and catalytic activity, and further propose that the formation of extra-framework Fe species at the cationic exchange sites within the zeolite channels is essential for achieving enhanced catalytic activity. Given the preparation of Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts with a range of Fe weight loadings, this section aims to establish a quantitative correlation between the presence of extra-framework Fe species and their catalytic MDA activity. All H-form Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts were subjected to the MDA test under identical conditions, and the results are plotted in Fig. 6 . All catalysts are active for benzene formation within the first GC point taken after introduction of methane. These catalysts undergo very rapid activation to attain the maximum benzene yield. Then, the activity declines gradually with TOS, similar to previous reports [55–58]. Given the limited temporal resolution of GC, transient kinetic measurements were next conducted using mass spectrometry to analyze the reaction products, with H-3.22 % serving as a representative example. As illustrated in Fig. S10, benzene formation is observed within seconds of initiating the methane feed and reaches its maximum yield at approximately 10 min TOS, demonstrating the rapid induction and activation of the catalyst. The detailed catalyst performance data (maximum CH4 conversion, maximum benzene yields, product distribution, and cumulative product yields) are provided in the Supporting Information. Usually, with the increase in metal loading, a higher product yield is expected. Nevertheless, this trend was not evident among the five Fe-ZSM-5-H catalysts and the Fe-ZSM-5-Na-2.58 % catalyst, suggesting that not all Fe sites may be active for MDA reaction. To establish a quantitative correlation, UV–Vis spectra of H-form catalysts, as well as Na-2.58 % catalyst, were fitted with two bands for two different framework Fe sites at 215 nm (5.77 eV) and 240 nm (5.17 eV) [5,59,60], and one band for isolated or low-oligomerized extra-framework Fe sites in the range of 250 (4.96 eV) –350 nm (3.54 eV), [61,62] and the results are summarized in Table 3 and Fig. S12. Note that the Fe species in Fe-ZSM-5 have been proven to have comparable molar absorptivity [63]. Moreover, Hammond et al. have applied a similar approach to an aqueous phase methane oxidation reaction [37,38], thereby providing additional validation for the present fitting approach. From the peak fitting analysis, the contribution of isolated or low-oligomerized Fe species at exchange sites (λ3) is quantifiable as the fraction of λ3 (λ3/λtotal). Subsequently, the quantity of isolated or low-oligomerized extra-framework Fe sites in each catalyst is defined as this fraction multiplied by the catalyst Fe weight loading (λ3/λtotal * Fe weight loading). Considering that MDA is intrinsically a non-steady state reaction, and there does not exist a ready steady-state metric of performance, the maximum methane conversion is employed here as a metric to represent the performance of catalysts. Fig. 7 shows the relationship between the quantity of isolated or low-oligomerized extra-framework Fe sites and the maximum methane conversion. A linear correlation is obtained, suggesting that the extra-framework Fe species function as the active sites for methane conversion. 3.4 Alternative supports for Fe species at exchange sites as active sites 3.4.1 Fe-Silicalite-1 Fe-Silicalite-1 is relatively more stable than Fe-ZSM-5 and is less likely to form extra-framework Fe species, owing to the absence of Al sites [64,65]. According to the above hypothesis, Fe-Silicalite-1 should exhibit significantly lower activity for methane activation, compared to Fe-ZSM-5. To test this hypothesis, Fe-Silicalite-1 was synthesized via a similar procedure, as documented in the Experimental Section. PXRD confirms its MFI structure (Fig. S13), while a comparable surface area and total pore volume of 370 m2/g and 0.21 cm3/g are determined by N2-physisorption (Fig. S13b). Fig. S13c presents the UV–Vis spectrum of the as-synthesized Fe-Silicalite-1, which is identical to that of the as-synthesized Fe-ZSM-5, suggesting that all Fe sites are incorporated within the framework. In contrast, the UV–Vis spectra of H-form Fe-Silicalite-1 and Fe-ZSM-5, as displayed in Fig. 8 a, exhibit a significant difference: Fe-Silicalite-1 shows a markedly less intense signal within the 250–350 nm range versus Fe-ZSM-5-DS-H. The same deconvolution process, as described above was applied to the UV–Vis spectrum of Fe-Silicalite-1-H-2.04 %, where the fraction of λ3 was calculated as 0.06, significantly lower than the H-form Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts. This observation confirms the limited migration of framework Fe sites to the extra-framework position in the Fe-Silicalite-1 case. Similarly, H-form Fe-Silicalite-1 was evaluated in the MDA test, conducted under identical conditions, and the results are compared to that of Fe-ZSM-5-DS-H-2.58 % in Fig. 8b and Fig. S14. As expected, Fe-Silicalite-1 demonstrates marginal activity in terms of both methane conversion and benzene selectivity. Moreover, the linear correlation between isolated or low-oligomerized extra-framework Fe sites and the maximum methane conversion still holds with the addition of the Fe-Silicalite-1-H result (Fig. 9 ). This observation again supports our hypothesis that extra-framework Fe species, generated during the activation, serve as the active sites for methane activation. 3.4.2 Fe-ZSM-5 Treated by different activation methods In this study, we also note that the MDA activity of Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts depends strongly on the pretreatment conditions. Another three Fe-ZSM-5 samples were prepared using the same hydrothermal synthesis method described above. ICP-OES, PXRD, N2-physisorption, and 27Al MAS NMR (Fig. S15) were utilized to confirm the physical characteristics of these samples, and detailed information is given in the Supporting Information. Furthermore, UV–Vis spectra of the as-synthesized samples provide evidence for the successful incorporation of Fe sites into the framework. Thus, prior to undergoing post-synthetic treatment, these samples exhibit properties comparable to the five samples described above. Subsequently, the three new materials were subjected to identical initial calcination and ion-exchange processes. Contrary to the previous five materials that were activated in static air without prior thorough drying, these samples were deliberately dried in a tube furnace under a dry air flow at 80 °C overnight before activation. Furthermore, the activation process was carried out in the same tube furnace under a continuous flow of dry air, with the temperature being incrementally raised to 550 °C at a rate of 1 °C per minute. The product H-form catalysts were evaluated under identical MDA conditions. Surprisingly, these catalysts exhibit significantly lower activity compared to the previous five catalysts that were calcined in the static air (Fig. S16). Upon comparing the UV–Vis spectra of these two batches of H-form catalysts (Fig. S17), it is evident that these latter samples exhibit a lower λ3 fraction than the previous samples, corresponding to a lower fraction of extra-framework Fe sites (Table 4 ). This observation again confirms that proper activation to form Fe species at the exchange sites is the prerequisite for high MDA catalytic activity. In addition, it is noteworthy that the correlation previously established between the quantity of isolated or low-oligomerized extra-framework Fe sites, as determined from the deconvolution of UV–Vis spectra, and the catalytic activity persists (Fig. 9). In contrast, no correlation is observed between Fe weight loading alone and catalyst activity, as shown in Fig. S18. This indicates that the fundamental relationship between iron site speciation and catalytic performance is maintained across varying degrees of activity. One possible cause of varied catalytic activity may arise from changes in the acidity of the zeolite. It is well-documented in the literature that the acidity of the zeolite has an impact on the product selectivity and yield of the MDA reaction [57,66,67]. Here we next conducted NH3-TPD measurements on two samples, H-3.22 % and H-3.13 %, which exhibit significantly different catalytic activities despite their similar compositions. The two samples also display comparable acidity profiles (Fig. S19), indicating that acidity is not the key differentiator. Instead, the difference in iron speciation is responsible for different catalytic activity, as discussed earlier. The literature suggests that the contents and position of Al sites [68], as well as water/humidity [22,69] and temperature [37,38] play important roles in the migration of Fe sites during the high-temperature treatment process. In this study, the materials were synthesized using identical hydrothermal methods and exhibit comparable Si/Al ratios of ∼20. Furthermore, Feng and Hall have shown that contents of the accessible Al pairs are high enough to anchor metal sites when Si/Al ratio approaches 40 [24]. Thus, it is safe to rule out the impact of Al sites in this study. Given the identical calcination temperature applied to both batch materials, the presence of water/humidity may be necessary for this process. Hammond et al. [37,38,70] compared zeolite samples calcined at different temperatures and concluded that a temperature >400 °C is effective in extracting the Fe sites in Fe-ZSM-5 materials. In this study, we adapted their method and incorporated certain modifications aimed at minimizing the impact of water. Specifically, the samples were thoroughly dried in a tube furnace under a flow of dry air at 80 °C overnight. Subsequently, activation was performed in the same tube furnace under a dry air flow, with the temperature being increased to 400, 550, and 750 °C at a ramp rate of 1 °C/min. Furthermore, to eliminate variability between synthesis batches, the sample from the previous batch (Sections 3.1–3.3), specifically Fe-ZSM-5-DS-NH4-2.58 %, after ion exchange, was utilized for conducting this temperature investigation. Fig. 10 a presents the UV–Vis spectra of H-form catalysts subjected to activation at temperatures of 400, 550, and 750 °C under a dry air flow. For comparative analysis, the spectrum of the catalyst activated at 550 °C in static air serves as the reference. Similar to the three samples discussed in the previous paragraph, the samples activated at 400 and 550 °C under a dry air flow exhibit a smaller λ3 fraction, indicating that the majority of Fe still remains in the framework. Upon increasing the temperature to 750 °C, UV–Vis bands above 350 nm are detected, indicating the formation of Fe oxide oligomers. Fig. 10b shows the catalytic results for the catalysts activated at 400, 550, and 750 °C under a dry air flow. Not surprisingly, a relatively low activity is observed for all cases. Considering that water involved in the calcination process was the only variable in this study, it is speculated that water/humidity and high temperatures act synergistically to facilitate the migration of Fe sites, leading to the formation of active extra-framework species. With this in mind, the observed activity of the NH4-form catalyst discussed in Section 3.2 can be explained. This activity can be attributed to the migration of some framework Fe sites during the temperature ramp-up to the reaction condition, as evidenced by the UV–Vis spectrum of the sample quenched immediately after the temperature elevation in He flow (Fig. S20a). A similar deconvolution analysis was applied to this spectrum, where signals above 350 nm are observed (Fig. S20b). Accordingly, another band was incorporated in this range, attributed to Fe oxide clusters λ4. To the best of our knowledge, highly dispersed Fe species anchored within zeolite channels are primarily responsible for activating CH4 [19,21]. However, no established analysis has quantitatively demonstrated how Fe oxide clusters contribute to methane activation. Therefore, we propose including the data points of both scenarios, with and without the contribution of Fe oxide clusters, into our relationship between the quantity of Fe speciation and maximum CH4 conversion, specifically in Fig. 9. Note that, in the scenario where the contribution of iron oxide clusters is included, an equal contribution of λ3 and λ4 is assumed. As shown in Fig. S21, the data point excluding the contribution of Fe oxide clusters fits perfectly within the correlation (Fig. 9) between maximum CH4 conversion and Fe speciation. In contrast, the data point incorporating the contribution of iron oxide clusters deviates slightly from this correlation compared to the prior one. This again demonstrates that isolated or low-oligomerized Fe sites within the zeolite channels are active sites for methane conversion. The catalytic behaviors of Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts in this work are similar to those of Fe/ZSM-5 catalysts prepared by the ion exchange method, as reported by this laboratory previously [19] and in the study conducted by Xu et al. [21]. Both types of catalysts do not experience a long induction and activation period, and exhibit a markedly higher maximum activity compared to IWI catalysts. Our previous study and that of Xu et al. identified that the active sites in ion-exchanged catalysts are isolated or low-oligomerized Fe species at the cationic exchange sites within the zeolite channels. They undergo a rapid reduction to form active iron suboxides in the He treatment (temperature ramp-up) process and in the methane flow, leading to rapid activation. Furthermore, since the majority of Fe sites are within the zeolite channels, there may be an accelerated accumulation of the hydrocarbon pool. This phenomenon further contributes to rapid activation and elevated benzene yields [71]. Considering that the Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts in this work possess identical active sites, it is assumed that they follow the same mechanism as those of the ion-exchanged catalysts (Fig. 11 ). Meanwhile, Fe sites remaining in the framework do not contribute to the methane activation but instead act as Brønsted acid sites, analogous to the framework Al sites. 4 Conclusions In this work, isomorphously substituted Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts were prepared by a one-pot hydrothermal method with a chelating agent EDTA added as a metal ion stabilizer. The properties of as-synthesized zeolites were confirmed by XRD, N2 – physisorption, SEM, 27Al MAS NMR, and Raman spectroscopy. The evaluation of Fe species during post-synthetic treatment was investigated by XAS and UV–Vis techniques. These results reveal that the as-synthesized Fe-ZSM-5 materials initially contain exclusively framework Fe sites, which partially migrate to extra-framework sites as a result of partial steaming during post-synthetic treatment, forming isolated or low-oligomerized Fe species at the exchange sites. These H-form catalysts exhibit no induction or activation period and exhibit significantly higher maximum benzene yields compared to catalysts with aggregated Fe2O3 domains, such as those prepared by the incipient wetness impregnation method. A quantitative correlation between isolated or low-oligomerized Fe species at the exchange sites and maximum CH4 conversion is established through UV–Vis spectroscopic deconvolution, indicating that these extra-framework Fe species serve as the active sites for methane conversion. Based on these findings, a deeper understanding of the correlation between active Fe sites and MDA activity is thereby acquired. By optimizing the presence of isolated or low-oligomerized Fe species at the cationic exchange sites, Fe-based ZSM-5 catalysts with improved performance—featured by a shorter activation period and higher benzene production—can be rationally designed and synthesized, presumably via ion-exchange of HZSM-5 with Fe2+ [21], and the rational design of the zeolite structures [68]. This advancement paves the way for more efficient catalytic systems, thereby enhancing the practical applications of MDA in methane conversion. coredata.dc:description: Methane dehydroaromatization (MDA) enables the catalytic conversion of methane into aromatics, mainly benzene, along with hydrogen, in a single-step process under non-oxidative conditions. In this study, we prepared a series of isomorphously substituted Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts with exclusively isolated or low-oligomerized sites up to 3.2 % Fe weight loading by adding ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) to the crystallization gel. These catalysts exhibit no induction/activation period and a significantly higher maximum product yield compared to Fe/ZSM-5 catalysts prepared by the incipient wetness impregnation method and containing extensively aggregated FeOx. This investigation focuses on the evolution of Fe sites during the post-synthetic treatments. Most importantly, we demonstrate the quantitative relation between Fe site isolation and catalytic activity, proving that isolated or low-oligomerized Fe species at the exchange sites formed during post-synthetic treatment are the active sites for methane activation.

coredata.dc:title: Identification and evolution of active sites in isomorphously substituted Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts for methane dehydroaromatization (MDA)
